stem: A 43-year-old female presents with episodes of intense headaches, heart pounding, and severe sweating. Based on the provided information, select the most likely condition, the two most appropriate nursing actions, and the two most important parameters to monitor.

tabs.title: SBAR
tabs.content:
Situation: Investigation of episodic hypertensive crises.
Background: Episodes occur during exercise or times of stress. No prior history of hypertension.
Assessment: Client is currently experiencing an episode. She is tremulous and reporting a 'pounding' sensation in her chest.
Recommendation: 24-hour VMA and metanephrine urine collection.

tabs.title: Hypertension Evaluation
tabs.content:

Blood Pressure238/122 mmHg (Critical)Severe HTN
Serum T3 / T4NormalRule out Thyroid Storm
Urine MetanephrinesElevated (Pending 24hr)Points to Adrenal Medulla
Abdominal CTMass noted on Right Adrenal GlandPheochromocytoma

tabs.title: Vital Signs
tabs.content: BP 238/122 mmHg, HR 122 bpm, RR 26 breaths/min, T 98.6°F (37°C). Skin is diaphoretic.

actionOptions.text: Provide a quiet environment and minimize stimulation.
Encourage the client to drink caffeinated beverages.

rationale.correct: The client's symptoms (headache, palpitations, sweating) and the presence of an adrenal mass on CT scan strongly suggest pheochromocytoma (c2). Normal thyroid labs rule out thyroid storm. Nursing actions should focus on minimizing stimulation to prevent further catecholamine release (a1) and avoiding abdominal palpation, which could trigger a hypertensive crisis (a2). Monitoring blood pressure (p1) and neurological status (p2) are crucial for detecting and managing complications.
clinicalPearls: Pheochromocytoma is a rare tumor of the adrenal medulla that secretes excessive catecholamines (epinephrine and norepinephrine).
Alpha-adrenergic blockade is typically initiated before beta-adrenergic blockade in the management of pheochromocytoma to prevent unopposed alpha-adrenergic stimulation.
The classic triad of pheochromocytoma includes headache, palpitations, and diaphoresis.

questionTrap.trap: Administering a beta-blocker immediately to address the elevated heart rate.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: In pheochromocytoma, beta-blockers should only be administered after alpha-blockade has been established to prevent unopposed alpha-adrenergic vasoconstriction and a hypertensive crisis.
